feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.summary: Monitoring message only. Please disregard.

entry.title: Wind Advisory issued October 23 at 10:21AM MDT until October 23 at 9:00PM MDT by NWS Boise ID
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Northwest winds 20 to 30 mph with gusts up to 45 mph expected along the cold front. Strongest near Mountain Home.
* WHERE...Southwest Highlands and Upper Treasure Valley.
* WHEN...From 6 PM to 9 PM MDT this evening.
* IMPACTS...Gusty winds will blow around unsecured objects. Tree limbs could be blown down.

cap:parameter.value: WIND ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 6 PM TO 9 PM MDT THIS EVENING

entry.summary:
* WHAT...West winds 20 to 30 mph with gusts up to 50 mph expected along the cold front.
* WHERE...Southern Twin Falls County and Western Magic Valley.
* WHEN...From 9 PM this evening to midnight MDT tonight.
* IMPACTS...Gusty winds will blow around unsecured objects. Tree limbs could be blown down.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Western Magic Valley; Southern Twin Falls County

cap:parameter.value: WIND ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 9 PM THIS EVENING TO MIDNIGHT MDT TONIGHT

entry.title: Dense Fog Advisory issued October 23 at 8:31AM PDT until October 23 at 12:00PM PDT by NWS Spokane WA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Visibility as low as a quarter mile in dense fog.
* WHERE...Spokane Valley, Flowery Trail Road, Kettle Falls, Colville, Ione, Newport, Airway Heights, Athol, Northport, Springdale-Hunters Road, Chewelah, Hayden, Metaline, Coeur d'Alene, Cheney, Clark Fork, Post Falls, Davenport, Bonners Ferry, Eastport, Downtown Spokane, Orin-Rice Road, Tiger, Schweitzer Mountain Road, Worley, Fruitland, Fairfield, Priest River, Deer Park, Rockford, Metaline Falls, and Sandpoint.
* WHEN...Until noon PDT today.
* IMPACTS...Low visibility could make driving conditions hazardous.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northern Panhandle; Coeur d'Alene Area; Spokane Area; Northeast Mountains

cap:parameter.value: DENSE FOG ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL NOON PDT TODAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 23 at 11:31AM EDT by NWS Albany NY
entry.summary: Minimum relative humidity values will drop to 28 to 40 percent this afternoon combined and south to southwesterly winds will become gusty at 20 to 30 mph across portions of the Adirondacks, upper Hudson Valley, Capital District, Catskills, Taconics, and Mid Hudson Valley. Fine fuels are dry according to the New York Department of Environmental Conservation, which in combination with the low relative humidity and breezy conditions will contribute to an elevated risk of fire spread during the afternoon.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northern Herkimer; Hamilton; Southern Fulton; Montgomery; Northern Saratoga; Northern Warren; Northern Washington; Schoharie; Western Schenectady; Eastern Schenectady; Southern Saratoga; Western Albany; Eastern Albany; Western Rensselaer; Eastern Rensselaer; Western Greene; Eastern Greene; Western Columbia; Eastern Columbia; Western Ulster; Eastern Ulster; Western Dutchess; Eastern Dutchess; Northern Fulton; Southeast Warren; Southern Washington

cap:parameter.value: ELEVATED RISK FOR FIRE WEATHER SPREAD THIS AFTERNOON

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 23 at 11:31AM EDT by NWS Albany NY
entry.summary: Relative humidities of 30 to 40 percent are expected today across much of Berkshire County in Massachusetts, along with above normal temperatures. Southwest winds are expected to be around 15 mph with gusts 20 to 30 mph. When factoring in the recent lack of rainfall, conditions favoring wildfire spread are again possible. Use caution when handling and disposing of ignition sources.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 23 at 11:31AM EDT by NWS Albany NY
entry.summary:
A combination of dry and windy conditions will create fire weather concerns this afternoon. Fine fuels remain very dry according to the Vermont Department of Forests. Low relative humidity values of 30 to 40 percent and gusty southwest winds of 20 to 30 mph are also expected. If any fires were to start, the weather and fuel conditions could cause them to quickly get out of control and be difficult to contain.
For more information about the current fire danger rating, any burn restrictions, and wildfire prevention and education, please visit your state forestry or environmental protection website.

cap:parameter.value: FIRE WEATHER CONCERNS EXIST ACROSS SOUTHERN VERMONT TODAY

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 23 at 11:12AM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
St Johns River Near Above Lake Harney affecting Seminole County.
.The river at Geneva near Lake Harney is forecast to continue a gradual decline in Moderate Flood Stage through this week. Residents and interests along the St. Johns River near Lake Harney should stay up to date on the forecast this week and prepare for prolonged flood impacts.
For the St. Johns River...including Above Lake Harney...Moderate flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued this evening at 1100 PM EDT.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...St Johns River near Above Lake Harney.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 9.5 feet, Water begins to move into homes in low lying areas along the river. Flooding around the Black Hammock area near Lake Jesup.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:30 AM EDT Wednesday the stage was 9.6 feet. - Bankfull stage is 6.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 10:30 AM EDT Wednesday was 9.7 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood stage at 9.6 feet. - Flood stage is 8.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 23 at 11:08AM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
St Johns River Near Sanford affecting Seminole County.
.The river at Sanford is forecast to continue to decline in Moderate Flood Stage and very close to the threshold for Minor Flood Stage through this week and into Minor Flood Stage into the weekend. Residents and interests along the St. Johns River at Sanford should stay up to date on the forecast this week and prepare for prolonged flood impacts.
For the St. Johns River...including Sanford...Moderate flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued this evening at 1100 PM EDT.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...St Johns River near Sanford.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 7.0 feet, Water begins to move over sea wall around Lake Monroe and rises into grassy areas around the sea wall. Water begins to encroach on Seminole Boulevard.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:30 AM EDT Wednesday the stage was 7.0 feet. - Bankfull stage is 4.2 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 10:30 AM EDT Wednesday was 7.1 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood stage at 7.0 feet. - Flood stage is 5.5 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 23 at 11:05AM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
St Johns River Near Deland affecting Volusia and Lake Counties.
.The river level at Deland remains in Major Flood Stage, and is forecast to remain steady around 5.4 feet through this week before it's expected to gradually decline into the weekend. Residents and interests along the St. Johns River at Deland should be prepared for Major flood impacts.
For the St. Johns River...including Deland ...Major flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued this evening at 1100 PM EDT.
* WHAT...Major flooding is occurring and major flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...St Johns River near Deland.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 5.3 feet, Major flooding occurs to many structures and marinas along the river and in the Hontoon Island area.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:30 AM EDT Wednesday the stage was 5.4 feet. - Bankfull stage is 3.5 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 10:30 AM EDT Wednesday was 5.4 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 5.4 feet this afternoon. - Flood stage is 4.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 23 at 11:01AM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
St Johns River Near Astor affecting Volusia and Lake Counties.
.The Saint Johns River at Astor will remain in Major Flood Stage for the foreseeable future. Breezy onshore winds have caused river levels to hold steady between 4.1 and 4.2 feet, and are then forecast to continue a gradual decline through the remainder of the weekend into next week. Residents and interests along the Saint Johns River should be prepared for prolonged major flood impacts.
For the St. Johns River...including Astor...Major flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued this evening at 1115 PM EDT.
* WHAT...Major flooding is occurring and major flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...St Johns River near Astor.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 4.0 feet, Major flooding occurs with water entering many structures on canals and along the river. Long duration flooding will occur, with levels taking weeks to months to return below flood stage. Water rescues will be necessary. River Road becomes inaccessible, with 1 to 2 feet water depth in numerous homes on Wildhog, Possum, Bonnet and Snail roads. Roads along Blue Creek are inaccessible with major flooding of homes on Otter, Branch and Chestnut roads. Camp South Moon Road and Juno Trail are inaccessible.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:30 AM EDT Wednesday the stage was 4.2 feet. - Bankfull stage is 2.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 10:30 AM EDT Wednesday was 4.3 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 4.2 feet this afternoon. - Flood stage is 2.3 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Frost Advisory issued October 23 at 7:55AM PDT until October 24 at 8:00AM PDT by NWS Portland OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Temperatures as low as 36 will result in frost formation.
* WHERE...In Oregon, North Oregon Coast Range and North Oregon Coast Range Lowlands. In Washington, South Washington Cascade Foothills.
* WHEN...From midnight tonight to 8 AM PDT Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Frost could harm sensitive outdoor vegetation. Sensitive outdoor plants may be killed if left uncovered.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The Frost Advisory that was in effect for October 23rd has expired due to warming temperatures. Some valley locations may continue to see localized frost on exposed surfaces.
entry.cap:areaDesc: North Oregon Coast Range Lowlands; North Oregon Coast Range; South Washington Cascade Foothills

cap:parameter.value: FROST ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM MIDNIGHT TONIGHT TO 8 AM PDT THURSDAY

entry.title: Freeze Warning issued October 23 at 7:55AM PDT until October 24 at 8:00AM PDT by NWS Portland OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Sub-freezing temperatures as low as 30 expected.
* WHERE...Upper Hood River Valley.
* WHEN...From midnight tonight to 8 AM PDT Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Frost and freeze conditions could kill crops, other sensitive vegetation and possibly damage unprotected outdoor plumbing.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The Frost Advisory that was in effect for October 23rd has expired due to warming temperatures. Some valley locations may continue to see localized frost on exposed surfaces.

cap:parameter.value: FREEZE WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM MIDNIGHT TONIGHT TO 8 AM PDT THURSDAY

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 23 at 10:27AM EDT until October 23 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Tampa Bay Ruskin FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
Withlacoochee At US 41 Dunnellon affecting Levy and Citrus Counties.
Withlacoochee River At Croom affecting Pasco and Sumter Counties.
Withlacoochee At SR 200 Holder affecting Citrus County.
Withlacoochee At US 301 Trilby affecting Pasco and Hernando Counties.
Cypress Creek At SR 54 Worthington Gardens affecting Pasco County.
Peace River At Bartow affecting Polk County.
Peace River At Arcadia at SR 70 affecting DeSoto County.
For the Withlacoochee...including US 301 Trilby, Croom, SR 200 Holder, US 41 Dunnellon...Major flooding is forecast. For the Cypress Creek...including SR 54 Worthington Gardens...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Peace...including Bartow, Arcadia at SR 70...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Peace River at Arcadia at SR 70.
* WHEN...Until this evening.
* IMPACTS...At 11.0 feet, Access roads to river acres become flooded.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:30 AM EDT Wednesday the stage was 11.0 feet. - Bankfull stage is 10.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 9:30 AM EDT Wednesday was 11.6 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage this afternoon and continue falling to 8.8 feet Monday morning. - Flood stage is 11.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 11.0 feet on 02/21/1998. - https://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL THIS EVENING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 23 at 5:26AM EDT by NWS State College PA
entry.summary:
A combination of dry and windy conditions will create an elevated risk of wildfire spread across mainly southern Pennsylvania today. Minimum relative humidity values dip into the 30 to 40 percent range this afternoon accompanied by wind gusts between 15 and 25 MPH. The highest gusts will be over the Laurel Highlands where they may get to 30 MPH.
Residents are urged to exercise caution if handling any potential ignition sources, such as machinery, cigarettes, or matches. If dry grasses and tree litter begin to burn, the fire will have the potential to spread rapidly.
For more information about wildfire danger and wildfire prevention and education, please visit the Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources website at http://dcnr.pa.gov/Communities/Wildfire.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 23 at 4:27AM EDT by NWS Albany NY
entry.summary:
A combination of dry and windy conditions will create fire weather concerns this afternoon. Fine fuels remain very dry according to the Vermont Department of Forests. Low relative humidity values of 30 to 40 percent and gusty southwest winds of 20 to 30 mph are also expected. If any fires were to start, the weather and fuel conditions could cause them to quickly get out of control and be difficult to contain.
For more information about the current fire danger rating, any burn restrictions, and wildfire prevention and education, please visit your state forestry or environmental protection website.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 23 at 4:27AM EDT by NWS Albany NY
entry.summary: Relative humidities of 30 to 40 percent are expected today across much of Berkshire County in Massachusetts, along with above normal temperatures. Southwest winds are expected to be around 15 mph with gusts 20 to 30 mph. When factoring in the recent lack of rainfall, conditions favoring wildfire spread are again possible. Use caution when handling and disposing of ignition sources.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 23 at 4:02AM EDT by NWS Burlington VT
entry.summary:
The combination of low humidities, gusty winds and a recent dry spell will create fire weather concerns today. Fine fuels remain very dry according to the Vermont Department of Forests, Parks and Recreation and the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation. Minimal relative humidity values of 25 to 35 percent and gusty southwest winds of 20 to 35 mph are expected. The lowest humidities and strongest winds will occur between 11 AM and 4 PM today. If any fires were to start, the weather and fuel conditions could cause them to quickly get out of control and be difficult to contain.
For more information about the current fire danger rating, any burn restrictions, and wildfire prevention and education, please visit your state forestry or environmental protection website.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 23 at 3:49AM EDT by NWS Mount Holly NJ
entry.summary:
There is an increased risk of fire spread this afternoon. Relative humidity values are expected to fall to around 30 to 40 percent across much of the area. This will be combined with south to southwest winds near 10 to 15 mph with gusts up to 20 mph, temperatures in the mid to upper 70s, and abundant sunshine. These conditions will support the spread of any fires that ignite, which could quickly become difficult to control.
Outdoor burning is strongly discouraged. Be sure to properly extinguish or dispose of any potential ignition sources, including smoking materials such as cigarette butts. Refer to your state's forest fire management agency for more information on burn restrictions in your local area.
Relative humidity values will be lower Thursday, with stronger winds. Burn restrictions may still be in place given the very dry conditions and lack of any recent rainfall.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 23 at 5:19PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
A strong westerly monsoon pattern persists across western Micronesia. The worst conditions are found between Yap and Chuuk and areas south. Satellite data has shown squalls racing southeastward at 35-45 mph, between 140E and 150E, bringing brief heavy showers, damaging gusts, and rapidly spiking seas in the 10-15 ft range. Northwesterly flow between Yap and Chuuk will turn westerly Thursday, possibly increasing as 98W, currently near Chuuk, shifts farther westward. The duration of this monsoonal flow and its impacts will be dependent on 98W and its motion.
This monsoonal pattern will make inter-island travel hazardous and potential dangerous at times so travel is discouraged through the rest of week and possibly the weekend. Watch out for high surf along west and north facing reefs and pay attention to surf and sea conditions.
Residents across the Yap and Chuuk States should continue to monitor local weather forecasts the next several days from the National Weather Service in Guam, and for additional information from your local Weather Service Office and emergency management. Visit weather.gov/gum/PublicForecasts for the latest weather information from the National Weather Service.

cap:parameter.value: STRONG MONSOONAL PATTERN ACROSS EASTERN YAP AND WESTERN CHUUK STATES

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 23 at 3:15PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
A tropical disturbance, known as Invest 98W from the Joint Typhoon Warning Center, continues to slowly develop near Chuuk at 8.1N 151.2E. This system will slowly continue westward before turning towards the Marianas around Friday, gradually strengthening as it does so. Computer model guidance continues to highlight the potential for this developing system to pass through the Marianas.
POTENTIAL IMPACTS: - Sustained winds exceeding 30 mph.
- Locally heavy rainfall potentially causing flash flooding, especially in areas of poor drainage or in the valleys of hilly terrain.
- Hazardous surf and marine conditions.
As this disturbance is still poorly organized, uncertainty remains high regarding the timing of its eventual consolidation and turn to the northwest. Continue to monitor latest forecasts from weather.gov/gum and information from your local emergency management offices.

cap:parameter.value: DEVELOPING TROPICAL DISTURBANCE ANTICIPATED TO AFFECT THE REGION SOMETIME BETWEEN FRIDAY AND SUNDAY... ...RAIN AND WIND POTENTIAL DEPENDENT ON THE EVENTUAL MOTION
